From the evening of Friday 20th May the Great Western Railway broad guage railway line was suspended for two days. Normal service was resumed on the morning of Monday 23rd May 1892, by which the time the distance between the rails had been narrowed from 7ft. to 4ft 8.5 inches.
I do not know what the distance is between Paddington and Penzance but this was quite a feat of engineering in such a short periood of time. They say it took 5,000 men working that weekend.

comment.author: 33075566@N08
comment._content:
The locomotive was appropriately the 8' single "Great Western" built at Swindon only four years previously. Like most broad gauge engines it was scrapped after the conversion.

Incidentally, the description of the photo quotes two different dates. The first one (20th May) is correct.
